case_name: Landholder (Proprietor of Kharma Hat) v. Local Board of Barpeta

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 630 of 1963 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 630 of 1963. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated June 8, 1959 of Assam High Court in Civil Rule No. 42 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated June 8, 1959 the Assam High Court in Civil Rule No. 42 of 1957. N. Mukherjee, for the appellant.

facts.text: Assam High Court dismissed the writ petition.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court repelled the contentions raised on behalf of the appellant and dismissed the writ petition.

facts.text: Assam High Court granted certificate under Art. 132 of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: As however, questions of constitutional importance were involved, the High Court granted a certificate under Art. 132 of the Constitution

facts.text: Appellant is a landholder in the district of Kamrup.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a landholder in the district of i Kamrup. As such landholder, he holds a hat or market

facts.text: Appellant holds a hat or market known as Kharma hat on his land since 1936.

anchor.surface_text: As such landholder, he holds a hat or market on his land since the year 1936 and this market is known as Kharma hat.

facts.text: Local board of Barpeta issued notice to appellant to take licence and pay Rs. 600/- for 1953-54 as licence-fee for holding Kharma market.

anchor.surface_text: In 1953-54, the local board of Barpeta, within whose jurisdiction the Kharma market is held, issued notice to the appellant to take out a licence and pay Rs. 600/-

facts.text: Licence fee increased to Rs. 700/- for 1955-56.

anchor.surface_text: Later this sum was increased to Rs. 700/- for the year 1955-56. The appellant continued protesting against this levy

facts.text: Amount sought to be recovered by distress warrants and attachment of appellant's property.

anchor.surface_text: but no heed was paid to his protests and the amount was sought to be recovered by issue of distress warrants and attachment of his property.

facts.text: Appellant filed writ petition in High Court challenging constitutionality of the tax.

anchor.surface_text: Consequently, the appellant filed a writ petition in the High Court challenging the constitutionality of the impost on a number of grounds.

facts.text: Appellant contended Assam legislature had no competence to tax markets.

anchor.surface_text: In the present appeal two main contentions have been urged in support of the appellants case that the impost is unconstitutional, namely, i that the Assam legislature

facts.text: Appellant contended tax on Kharma market infringes Art. 14.

anchor.surface_text: ii that the tax actually imposed on the Kharma market infringes Art. 14 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Respondent relies on item 49 of List II, Seventh Schedule: tax on land.

anchor.surface_text: This attack on behalf of the appellant is met by the respondent by relying on item 49 of List II of the Seventh Schedule to the Constitution, and it is urged

facts.text: Rule under s.62 prescribes Rs.1000/- as maximum tax on markets licensed under s.62.

anchor.surface_text: As to Art. 14, the reply on behalf of the respondent is that under s. 62 of the Act, a rule has been framed prescribing Rs. 1000/- as the maximum amount of tax

facts.text: Local board may impose tax within maximum according to size and importance of market with govt approval.

anchor.surface_text: which may be levied by any local board in Assam on markets licensed under that section. The rule also provides that any local board may with the previous approval

facts.text: Tax imposed by Barpeta local board in accordance with the rule.

anchor.surface_text: of Government impose a tax within this maximum according to the size and importance of a market. So it is submitted that the tax has been imposed by Barpeta

facts.text: Appellant alleged board fixed high rate arbitrarily, discriminating against Kharma market compared to neighbouring markets with lower rates.

anchor.surface_text: In that connection, all that the appellant has stated in his writ petition is that the board fixed a high rate arbitrarily and thus discriminated against the appellants

facts.text: Tax imposed for 1953-54, continued later with modifications; five markets taxed including Kharma.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the tax was imposed for the year 1953-54. which was continued later on, with some modifications. At that time there were five markets

facts.text: Taxes on five markets: Rs.400 on two, Rs.500 on one, Rs.600 on Kharma, Rs.1000 on one.

anchor.surface_text: on which the tax was imposed including the Kharma market. The lowest tax was at Rs. 400/- on two markets, then at Rs. 500/- on the third market and at Rs. 600/-

facts.text: Rule 300 framed under s.63 fixes Rs.1000 max tax, graduated by size and importance.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 300 2 , flamed in accordance with s. 63 3 runs thus--- Rs. 1000/- Rupees one thousand only per annum has been fixed as the maximum amount of tax

facts.text: Kharma market taxed at Rs.600/- per year.

anchor.surface_text: it is not possible to hold that there was discrimination in taxing Kharma market at Rs. 600/- per year as compared to taxing the three other markets

issues.text: whether the impost in the present case is a tax on land within the meaning of entry 49 of List II of the Seventh Schedule to the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: The first question which falls for consideration therefore is whether the impost in the present case is a tax on land within the meaning of entry 49 of List II of the Seventh Schedule to the Constitution.

arguments.claim: Assam legislature had no legislative competence to tax markets

anchor.surface_text: that the Assam legislature had no legislative competence to tax markets, and ii that the tax actually imposed on the Kharma market infringes Art. 14 of the Constitution. We shall therefore consider these two contentions only.

anchor.surface_text: It is well-settled that the entries in the three legislative lists have to be interpreted in their widest amplitude and therefore if a tax can reasonably be held to be a tax on land it will come within entry 49.

arguments.claim: Classification by size and importance of market is valid under Art.14

anchor.surface_text: Any local board may with the previous approval of Government impose a tax within this maximum according to the size and importance of a market. Now the rule provides that Rs. 1000/- is the maximum tax

arguments.claim: No material to judge relative size/importance; no discrimination proved

anchor.surface_text: But no such facts and figures have been adduced on behalf of the appellant... As there is no material before us by which we can judge the relative size and importance of the five markets, it is not

holdings.text: the tax provided therein is a tax on land, though its incidence depends upon the use of the land as a market

anchor.surface_text: We have therefore no hesitation in coming to the conclusion on a consideration of the scheme of s. 62 of the Act that the tax provided therein is a tax on land, though its incidence depends upon the use of the land as a market.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Scheme of s.62 imposes liability on owner/occupier of land used as market; tax annual on land not transactions; 'thereon' refers to land; use taken into account per settled law on annual value.

holdings.text: Thus the tax in the present case being on land would clearly be within the competence of the State legislature

anchor.surface_text: Further as we have already indicated s. 62 2 which uses the words impose an annual tax thereon clearly shows that the word thereon refers to any land for which a licence is issued for use as a market and not to the word market. Thus the tax in the present case being on land would clearly be within the competence of the State legislature.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pith and substance is tax on land under entry 49 List II given widest amplitude; no need for specific entry on markets.

holdings.text: The contention of the appellant that the State legislature was not competent to impose this tax because there is no provision in List II of the Seventh Schedule for imposing a tax on markets as such must therefore fail

anchor.surface_text: Thus the tax in the present case being on land would clearly be within the competence of the State legislature. The contention of the appellant that the State legislature was not competent to impose this tax because there is no provision in List II of the Seventh Schedule for imposing a tax on markets as such must therefore fail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects claim of lack of competence as tax is on land not markets; items 28/66 do not preclude.

holdings.text: it is for the person who alleges that equality before law has been infringed to show that such really is the case

anchor.surface_text: Then we come to the contention under Art. 14 of the Constitution. As to that it is well-settled that it is for the person who alleges that equality before law has been infringed to show that such really is the case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Well-settled burden of proof on challenger to adduce facts/figures proving discrimination under Art.14.

holdings.text: As there is no material before us by which we can judge the relative size and importance of the five markets, it is not possible to hold that there was discrimination in taxing Kharma market at Rs. 600/- per year as compared to taxing the three other markets

anchor.surface_text: But no such facts and figures have been adduced on behalf of the appellant. It is true that the respondent in reply to the charge of discrimination was equally vague and merely denied that there was any arbitrary discrimination.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appellant adduced no facts/figures on relative size/importance; classification per Rule 300 reasonable; no arbitrariness shown.

holdings.text: The attack therefore on the amount actually fixed on the ground of discrimination must fail

anchor.surface_text: As there is no material before us by which we can judge the relative size and importance of the five markets, it is not possible to hold that there was discrimination in taxing Kharma market at Rs. 600/- per year as compared to taxing the three other markets at less than Rs. 600/-. The attack therefore on the amount actually fixed on the ground of discrimination must fail.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Vague allegations insufficient; tax per graduated scale under rule not discriminatory without proof.

anchor.surface_text: We have therefore no hesitation in coming to the conclusion on a consideration of the scheme of s. 62 of the Act that the tax provided therein is a tax on land, though its incidence depends upon the use of the land as a market.

anchor.surface_text: Further as we have already indicated s. 62 2 which uses the words impose an annual tax thereon clearly shows that the word thereon refers to any land for which a licence is issued for use as a market and not to the word market. anchor.surface_text: Thus the tax in the present case being on land would clearly be within the competence of the State legislature. anchor.surface_text: But no such facts and figures have been adduced on behalf of the appellant. It is true that the respondent in reply to the charge of discrimination was equally vague and merely denied that there was any arbitrary discrimination.

anchor.surface_text: As there is no material before us by which we can judge the relative size and importance of the five markets, it is not possible to hold that there was discrimination in taxing Kharma market at Rs. 600/- per year as compared to taxing the three other markets at less than Rs. 600/-. The attack therefore on the amount actually fixed on the ground of discrimination must fail.
The High Court repelled the contentions raised on behalf of the appellant and dismissed the writ petition.
